review_title: Good environment but ulu location and lackluster compensation structure
pros: Given the size of the organization, your experience will vary significantly depending on your role, whether as cabin crew, pilot, ops or ground crew. I am commenting mainly as ground (office based) staff for SQ. The company has a collegial environment and there is much to learn from the various departments. Flight perks are great, and they do offer solid medical, dental benefits and insurance coverage. The work is challenging and there is satisfaction in working at a world class airline.
cons: However, all is not well. Attrition is high, especially for ground roles. We are losing many good and capable people because the salary structure simply isn't competitive to what the marketplace is offering. This is worsened in the very high inflation environment we are seeing. It is much more costly to hire replacements, train them well, only to lose them after one or two years because we don't compensate them well enough. Its a great pity. We seriously need to up the compensation structure to attract and retain talent. Further, career progression tends to be slow. Another major bugbear is the relatively ulu and run down location of its offices. The main HQ at airline house is old and very run down. It is in desperate need of major renovations. The offices are spacious but old and drab. The other major offices at STC and TechSQ are slightly better, but not by much more. Location in the far east is a major deterrent, especially for staff living in the north or west given the lengthy commute. To mitigate this, management should consider giving more wfh days and increased flexibility in working hours, or allow staff to work in satellite offices closer to central. Doing so will also give us the opportunity to upgrade or renovate the existing buildings. Food options at the canteens are also dire. There is no decent vegetarian options, many stalls are vacant.

review_title: Raw Honest Review - know what you are in for.
pros:
If you don’t mind being a yes-man in exchange for work-life balance and stability (slow growth)

SIA Employer Branding still has some clout; particularly in government sector.

Senior Mgmt are really solid people.
cons:
Quite a number of uninspiring self-preserving wayang middle management: 
(i) Lacks much needed domain knowledge and skills to produce real output or give proper work advice/ direction.
(ii) Lacks leadership skills and incentive to nurture team; probably due to job rotation every 3-5years. 
(iii) Risk averse to rock the boat, say no / do right by the team. Non-major decisions are (strangely) frequently put up for the highest paid person’s opinion; not unusual for many to have this as their 1st/2nd company and to-be final company.

Poor overall compensation package and benefits.

Selective to hire quality candidates, yet culture is particularly stifling for young ambitious employees: red tape, legacy baggage and job creation for paper shufflers to be managers. Not much work empowerment.

Office is very far and ulu.

Slow promotion and depends on knowing the right people.

pros:
1. Free travel to plenty of countries.

2. The pay is not bad, you don't bring home any work.
cons:
1. 3 months of training whereby you'll probably be scolded, nagged at and treated like literal kids by the trainers and office staff whom are probably just a decade older than you.

2. Seniority whilst flying is very apparent, some days you can never do anything right and it's ''normal'' to get picked on ever so often.

3. Promotion is not easy to get. Only if you're good at forging connections with the superiors on board; staff at the office; your direct superiors. + spending your off days to take up courses to get a good grade on the yearly review.

4. Outdated Culture; people side with the senior staff more than the junior one. In a he say she say, even though you might be right no one will believe you.

5. Get ready to miss out on important events like birthdays, weddings and holidays.

review_title: Don't join as Associates if looking for progression
pros:
- free yearly airplane ticket (taxable)
- people in my team were helpful
- got chance to work with people of diverse background
- the company still hold some prestige 
- can work until retirement job if you not looking for advancement
cons:
- low salary

- for ground staff there are the associate and the executive.  The associate are diploma holder and below while the executive are the university degree holder and above. There is a clear differential treatment between these 2 group of workers for the department I was in. For instance when there was an appreciation lunch, all the executive in the department were invited but associate only selected few.

- promotion for associate is very very slow. Always have to depend on the bell curve and estab. 

- rather hire a new executive from outside than to promote the experience and qualify associate 

- Salary increment for associate is negotiated with Union and standard "pricing" regardless effort of work done. 

- Digitalisation of the company still very slow compare to other companies 

- HR not doing much for staff welfare, always say it up to the discretion of the department head

review_title: A Great Way to Fly but not the best to work in
pros: Free firm load tickets, discounted subload tickets.
cons: Progression is very slow. Gen staff are second class of the corporate ladder. Leave package is very lacking. 5 years of working, leave entitlement is still tied to 15 days/year, carry forward leaves are to be cleared by March. To be able to get promotion, it is only possible if someone resigns, retires or transferred out. To be able to get transfer from one department to another, it is not as straight forward as it seems by application, shortlisted and attending interviews. Vacancy is put up in the system as a form of formality(fairness) but the management has already someone in mind to fill that position. Yearly increment is not attractive and it is not competitive as to meet the increasing cost of living.

review_title: PROs and CONs as an SQ cabin crew member
pros:
- The layovers in EU/NZ and US stations - as they were at least 48 hours above.
- The night stop/ layover allowance - technically the longer you stay in another country, you get more $.
- The training was very comprehensive and it needed to be intense to prepare me well for the actual flying duties.
cons:
- The culture can sometimes be very military and hierarchical in a way where new crew members might be forced to do unnecessary stuff/procedures, just to please the senior crew's ego. 

For example, 
Upon arrival at a station, the most junior female crew member has to initiate the TIPS collection for the bus driver during the journey to the hotel - if not you will be frowned upon (where trivial matters like this can be initiated by anyone, basically...)
 
- Promotion depends heavily on staff seniority rather than merits.

job_title: Flight Operations Officer, Flight Dispatcher in Singapore
pros: Benefits. And glamorous, nothing else.
cons: Cant compete salary to market. Poor management handling unless you suck up to them of course, because that's how they got the position in the first place as well. A LOT OF NATO. Empty promises around the company. Its a legacy company, suitable only for older generations where they can earn minimal, do work slowly and have 5 breaks in a day. NO CAREER PROGRESSION. All internal postings are just a sham. They'll hire external ultimately. Unless you have a degree and enter as an executive, you'll survive. Oh, minorities will have a lower chance as well OBVIOUSLY. Company is only surviving because of its strategic location, airport and support by govt. Credits to cabin crew as well for giving excellent service. Other than that, ground staff will be left to rot. Management will take advantage of you for their own gains, shuffling people creating redundant positions that basically sounds good but same thing.

review_title: Good work life balance and culture
pros:
Great company to be in with a comfortable working culture, many are genuinely passionate to be in aviation and proud of the brand. Little office politics and team spirit is valued.

Good employee benefits, like one FOC ticket per year and unlimited discounted tickets. Staff development and training is also well done with staff being rostered regularly by department heads and HR to attend in-house courses.
cons:
Salary is slightly below market rate.

Clear distinction between degree and non-degree holders even from the cubicle partitions and progression, and auto-exclusion of associates from meetings due to the fact that they are not degree holders. Very old school mindset favoring local uni grads; would externally hire a fresh grad instead of a non-degree holder already employed in the company for years. No guaranteed promotion for non-degree holders vs guaranteed promotions annually for degree holders.

review_title: Hierarchical culture, people environment, good welfare and benefits
pros:
- Great medical coverage and travel benefits
- Annual 1 free ticket seated in Premium Economy/Economy Class
- Unlimited discounted tickets (subjected to passenger load) on SIA, Scoot, Silkair, and other subsidiary/selected partner airlines
- Great working environment to meet multiple backgrounds and experiences of people
- Widen your knowledge and experiences on F&B, travel opportunities to main cities
- No strict curfews or restrictions, freedom to stay anywhere at base (no hostels)
- Plenty of self-directed courses to upskill and improve soft skills, courses that offer certification etc
- Always advocate positive values to boost morale
- Lots of curriculum activities and societies to join
- Celebrate cabin crew achievements and festive seasons
- Bonus/profit sharing every year
cons:
- Inflexible protocol or procedures to follow sometimes
- Not everyone is receptive towards your feedback or suggestions, sometimes can be authoritative and rigid on behaviour and gestures
- No opportunity to travel in business/first class on staff tickets
- Discounted tickets only for economy class
- Working flights only get to fly 1-2 main cities in a country instead of multiple smaller cities
- High competition and longer years to promote, metrics for promotion are sometimes unjustifiable and inflexible

review_title: Challenging Industry - Passion is a Must
pros:
a. Some divisions are better managed than the rest (e.g. Cabin, Flight Ops). For such divisions, there is a good worklife balance and strong employee satisfaction.
b. The SIA spirit is still strong even though aviation is no longer a golden industry (thin profit margin, vulnerable to external threats and competition), many are passionate of their work.
c. While other airlines are cutting jobs during Covid 19, Management are doing their best to retain employment. Generally there is concern for staff.
cons:
a. Some divisions have too much workload and the workload distribution within the divisions is uneven. 
b. There are some employees who are disengaged and they are not engaged to step up and improve. Some managers are overloaded with too many day to day responsibilities and they cannot make the switch to engage their staff.
c. Challenging industry during Covid 19 period. Must remain strong and work hard, in the face of paycuts and no bonus.

Culture has improved from what I've heard and experienced compared to earlier batches a decade or even 5 years before me. Would have stayed longer if I was younger.

pros:
Cabin crew team is awesome and are the reason for the companies success. Don't let the CEO or senior management steal the shine from them.
The people I worked with on a team level were kind and many are still my friends today.
Benefits (free dental, healthcare, etc).
Company looks good on CV
cons:
I worked in the IT department and it was a mess. The way they work is 10-15 years behind the rest of the world.
The IT department is going through an Agile transformation run by admin people with no IT experience and it is a dumpster fire inside of train wreck.

To be a manager, you have to work there for over 10 years and be liked. Being competent, knowing how to lead people or having basic social skills is not a prerequisite.

Management is very old school, hierarchical and have no idea what they are doing. It is just a boys club full of old men. They have never worked in any other company and it shows with their old school kiasu mindset.
Decision making process is not democratic. All decisions are made at the unqualified management level

IT is too dependent on cheap vendors. Results in slow delivery and inferior product.
Not many young people, stifling innovation.

Pay is below market level. During my time, IT HR did some number manipulation/cherrypicking to show it is at market level. We got a small pay-rise to make it look like action was being taken. It was an insult to all our intelligence.

From a diversity perspective, it is still in the dark ages. LGBTQ inclusion is not there. In fact, the LGBTQ community is not even mentioned.
In-flight, any films with LGBTQ references (they refer to it as "promoting homosexual lifestyle" in the internal guide) are banned.
This is very ironic given that many cabin crew themselves are LGBTQ, and they are the ones responsible for the companies great reputation.

review_title: Do not recommend to fresh grads
pros: Brand name. That's about it.
cons:
1. Practically the worst working location in SG (Airline House). There are shuttle buses from some pick up points but they are not free, and not even subsidised. One ride costs $1.50 min. 
2. Benefits are mediocre at best. One free ticket a year is not anything to shout about. It is also subjected to balloting so you might not even get the flight that you want. Company stinges on cost a lot in a discreet way. China brand stationery, no food and drinks in the pantry (depends on your department), and recently the fluoride treatment in dental appointments even got removed. 
3. Pay is definitely below market rate. Fresh grad average $3K starting pay (but varies by a few hundred dollars depending on your honours)
4.  Culture is not good (but really depends on your division). In my division, the managers are old (mostly in their 40s-50s) and closed minded and do not like people to voice out disagreements. You are expected to obide by the rules and procedures strictly. Very inflexible and stifling culture. Also, in the more operational departments, there are a lot of aunties/uncles doing admin work while waiting to retire. It does not make for a motivational and inspirational working environment for the younger generation. 
Nonetheless, there are many changes going on in the company right now.  Things might improve in the future.

review_title: Good to stay for two to three years but not forever
pros:
It’s definitely the best airlines to see the world because it has longer stay in outstations. Unlike Emirates and Qatar, which usually give crew only 24 hours to rest, SQ provides longer patter for crew in some stations. 
SIA provides reasonable allowance, sometimes a stewardess can hit 6000sgd, however if you’re a steward, you’ll get comparably lower because of the flight patterns you get. But please take note that SIA used to provide a much more better offer than now and it has been cutting down from year to year, which is one of the main reasons that I don’t recommend to stay for too long,
Famous for its service, you’ll absolutely learn a lot from this company, which is good for those who just graduated.
cons:
The culture of SIA is horrible. You have to show 100% respect to your seniors even sometimes they are being unreasonable. The company stands with those with high seniority. You get a hard time especially during training and probation. 
Secondly, this is the common downside for a lot of aircrew that since you’ll fly with different crew every time, it’s hard to build up a deeper relationship, so the topics you’ll have are quite limited, for example, the most common crew topic is what’s the good food in the supermarket nearby the crew hotel. 
If you’re a foreign crew, and you don’t really like to make friends initiatively, you’ll the a lonely life in Singapore, since all the crew you know are in outstations very often, it is not so easy to find common holiday to hang out.
